last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>246220446
Pucci fucked up his Made in Heaven technique by dying before a complete cycle. Which basically caused all his changes to snap back, like a rubber band. Also because of all the unshackled from fate shenanigans, by fucking up so hard instead of erasing all his enemies from the universe, he instead deleted himself from the timeline.

So the original souls of the cast were restored. You can tell because they look literally exactly like their old selves, unlike the soulless knockoff versions in Pucci's universe. Even though we didn't see it, I bet that Pucci's knockoff version did not have the Joestar star birthmark.

Anyway, because Pucci deleted himself from the timeline, that means that after DIO is defeated there's nobody to take control of his organization to keep fucking with Jotaro, which means that Jotaro can actually be a family man. Also for some reason Herme's sister is still alive and Annasui isn't a murderer.

Actually taking a look at the afterword.
>For ‘Jojo’s Bizarre Adventure’ I had to leave modern days and return to nature. I had to change Stone Ocean’s ending right before the last chapters for this reason, I brought out all the nostalgic feelings I had in my soul and this is why it came out like that. Jolyne Cujoh’s memories might be different in the reset of the universe but her love and her feelings are still there, they became something eternal and I’m sure she’ll keep growing wiser and stronger.

So basically even though the events no longer happened in the new timeline, all the experiences and things from the adventure were basically imprinted on the part 6 cast's soul. Which helped them change small things and reach a happier ending we can see at the end of Stone Ocean when they're reunited with Emperio.

I actually kind of like this interpretation, since it builds off Part 5's climax. "Righteous actions born of justice can never be destroyed." The results of their journey still remain, imprinted on their soul.

You keep comparing other humans, who can actively voice their thoughts in an understandable manner, to monkeys.
You are conflating psychic powers with being a completely different species that cannot be communicated with.

A comparison that actually makes sense is a person with a gun and a persona without a gun. For all intents and purposes, the person with the gun has complete control of the other person's life. The person without the gun is physically powerless to do anything.
So, because they are a human being, they can SPEAK to the person with the gun, to try and convince them not to. An animal fundamentally cannot do this, nor has any concept of what a gun is, and so your premise from the very start was flawed and meant nothing.

So, the person with the gun is automatically in the right because they can do whatever they want to the other person, because 'might makes right' and the person's verbal attempt to dissuade them didn't work.
So, a third person with a bigger, deadlier gun enters the scene. This person tells the original gun wielder to stop threatening the one without. They still do not budge. So, the third person shoots them in the leg before they shoot the unarmed person. Now this person can be talked to without the threat of further violence because they had to be stopped and restrained from causing harm.

In your mind, this is 'might makes right.' Because t the only solution was to shoot the offending person. When in truth, the first person with the gun had never thought about the feelings of others due to their upbringing. If they had a better childhood, they never would've picked up the gun in the first place.

Stop bringing animals into this because it completely fucks up what you're trying to say.

You should look at it from the other side.
The fact that we are struggling with cancer right now is an achievement.
Cancer is not a disease in the traditional sense (invading life-form leeching resources off of you and fucking with your body functions to hinder your bodily defenses). It's a consequence of humans living longer than they were designed for.
We are living healthier and longer lives than we evolved for. So long in fact, that a copy-paste bug with a tiny probability of happening per replication cycle actually has a reasonable chance of becoming a real problem.

Cancer is a first world problem.

And we are making progress with it. Having cancer today is a completely different diagnosis than it was 50 years ago.
There was a time not so long ago when it was considered a certain death sentence (which was why doctors didn't even give it to their patients).

>>246213971
The pacing and character development bothered me when I first watched it but upon rewatch it was totally fine, though Shinji's arc from immature child to mature adult still felt a little rushed. The animation which I wasn't a fan of originally is much better in theaters, the way each scene is composed and directed stands out more impressively, even the CGI was mostly used in a intelligent way and I'm not a fan of CGI in anime.
The third act is when it really came together for me. There's this sense of closure and finality to the story. It's like a play with the long dialogue stretches and the setting becoming an obvious set.
The ending which I originally construed as Anno telling the audience to touch grass felt more like him saying to move on from Evangelion, not to stop watching or talking about Eva but more so to stop making Evangelion a major part of your life.
The first act was also a lot better on rewatch. It's more along the lines of Anno's live action work like Ritual or Love and Pop, the camera moves as if it's real and reacting to the environment. I'm not typically a fan of animation trying to be live action but it works here because it's to directly contrast the galactic maximalism of the next hour. It's a real life away from the Evas which is exemplified by the direction. The slower pace functions well too, it's very character driven in order to make the rest of the film work. It's Shinji learning to be an adult and Rei finding purpose in life beyond piloting an Eva. Rei's character arc in the film rivals the show for the best stuff involving her character.

It may not have the same stakes or drama like later parts, at least before reaching Cairo, but it makes up for it with heart. All the stands are simple, characters are funny and memorable and the plot keeps you watching.

With that being said, we can come to an agreement that part 5 is actually when Jojo peaked.

>According to the "Tensonhongi" (original record of the heavenly grandchild) in "Sendai Kujihongi" (Ancient Japanese History), these treasures were bestowed by the Amatsukamimioya (heavenly ancestor) on Nigihayahi no Mikoto. In "Sendai Kujihongi," they were described as "amatsushirushi mizutakara tokusa" (ten kinds of heavenly-emblem sacred treasures).

>These ten are subdivided into four classes: two mirrors, one sword, four magadama (a comma-shaped bead), and three hire (scarves that women put over their shoulders and hang in the front on the both sides in the same length). One theory compares these ten with the Three Sacred Treasures of the Imperial Family, so the mirrors represent the Yata no Kagami (mirror), the sword and hire represent the Kusanagi no Tsurugi (sword), and the magadama represent the Yasakani no Magatama.

>The ten treasures consisted of the following:
>the Okitsukagami (Mirror of the Deep)
>the Hetsukagami (Mirror of the Shore)
>the Yatsuka no Tsurugi (The Eight Hands Long Sword)
>the Ikutama (Jewel of Life)
>the Makaru Kaeshi no Tama (Jewel of Resuscitation)
>the Tarutama (Jewel of Plenty)
>the Chikaeshi no Tama (Jewel of Turning Back on the Road)
>the Orochi no Hire (Snake[-repelling] Scarf): relation with the hire in the myth of Okuninushi is noticed.
>the Hachi no Hire (Bee[-repelling] Scarf): relation with the hire in the myth of Okuninushi is noticed.
>the Kusagusa no Mono no Hire (Scarf [to ward off] Various Things)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I'm always astonished at how much this filters everyone
Especially the pseud crowd, convinced that a manga with a slightly unusual storytelling is just here to "subvert their expectations"
Fire Punch isn't actually meta, everytime it uses fiction in the narrative, it's to reinforce its philosophical point about people and the role they give themselves in the shitty drama they call life
Fire Punch has nothing to say about the classic structure of manga storytelling it really doesn't give two shits about that. It's not here to comment on its own medium. It's not even here to comment on fiction itself but rather how everyone uses fiction to define their own purpose in life.
It really isn't lolsorandumb either. Honestly I don't even want to think just how many standardised shonentrash you need to have read for your sick mind to come to that conclusion.
Pseuds who go on and on about the two aforementioned points are just completely filtered. They try to interpret this manga according to the sotftware they use for every other piece of isekai trash they spend their days reading and bitching about. When in truth, Fujimoto really doesn't give a fuck about anyone's expectations, he just writes his story and damn you if you can't follow.
And apparently, three quarters of the speedreading morons on this board can't follow. And I haven't even started on the mongoloids who can't even understand the ending and come out convinced this is nihilisitic.
It's overall fucking brilliant, not only is the main point very interesting and completely unexpected from a mangaka who was like 21 when he started writing this shit, the paneling is fucking god-tier and the narration in general is among the best shit you can do with comic books in general.
when I read shit like "hurr durr Fujimoto is the pinnacle of zoomer writing" it really makes me wonder what the fuck I'm doing here, posting with literal fucking apes who should have stayed on reddit
